sp.p: Here, take them; do what you will with them: I will be guided by you—Yet this affair, of Langwood's letter—

sp.speaker: Fam.
sp.p: Will make dreadful confusion, my lord—Let me think, a little—I have it—Suppose we delay the delivery of it, for a few days; something may happen, in that time, that may save the unhappy Harriet the pain of such a discovery.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Tho' I have little hopes, on that account, yet wou'd I not precipitate her wretchedness; it was to save her from it, Frampton, that first induced me—

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Talk nomore of it, my lord—Mr. Willis—

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: So, they are friends, again, I see. (Aside.)—Did your honour call, Mr. Frampton?

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Take these letters, and give them to Sir William's servant, to be delivered, immediately.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: What, all of them, my lord?

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: No, this one must be kept back. Look it up, carefully, 'till I call for it.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Come, my dear Frampton, I have a thousand obligations to you, and a thousand things to speak to you, about.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p:
My dear Frampton!—There's a fellow for you, that, without half a crown in his pocket, talks as much stuff, about honour, and such nonsense, as if he were a duke—They have not broke the seal, I find; that's Frampton's fault: if he had not return'd, the instant he did, I wou'd have satisfied my lord's curiosity, and my own—Well, cannot I do so, now? A good servant shou'd prevent his master's
wishes—My lord, I am sure, would be glad to know the contents; egad, and so should I, too—but how shall I come at 'em?—This cursed seal (flirts it with his finger.) Zounds! what have I done?—what an accident! why, the letter's open?—why, if it is, one may read it, without offence—So, by your leave, good Mrs. Winifred— (reads) Madam, as I am sensible the dreadful moment now approaches, when I must render an account of all my actions—A steward's account will be tolerably long, I suppose. (Continues reading.) I wish, even by this late confession, to atone for the crime I have been guilty of, in aiding lord Eustace to impose upon your niece, by a feigned marriage.—The devil! This is a confession, indeed! for which, like all other mean-spirited, whimpering rascals, he deserves to be hanged. My lord was in the right, to look sharp, after this business—We must have been blown up, if it had come to light. But as I hope to be well paid, for the contents of this, I may let the others go free.

head.stage: SCENE changes to Sir William Evans's Apartment, HARRIET, seated on a Couch, leaning on her Arm.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
I cannot pierce thro' the mystery, in which I am involved. I strive, in vain, to recover my confidence in lord Eustace. These fatal reports unhinge my very soul—Yet nothing can abate my love. One false step has involved me, in a thousand difficulties. I can endure my situation, no longer; and let the consequence be what it may, I will reveal the secret, to my father. But then, my lord's intreaties, and my aunt's commands—why even they must be sacrificed, to filial duty—Wretch,
that I am, how did I dare to break that first of moral ties!—Heavens! he is here!
sp.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM, with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I have just received a letter, from your brother, Harriet, which I should have had, ten days ago, had I been at home.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Does he assign a cause, for coming to London, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis as Loyd guessed, an affair of galantry, but an honourable business, tho'—I long 'till ye are both married, that I may hear no more of romances. I hope, when Harry has led the way, you will have no objection to follow him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What shall I say to him?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wish I knew who my future daughter-in-law is to be. Harry tells me she has a great fortune; but that, I suppose, is a sweetener—But if she has worth and virtue, sufficient to make him happy, I shall be content.—But what's the matter, Harriet? I thought your illness was quit gone off—you look as if you had been weeping—My sister, I suppose—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, Sir; indeed her goodness to me, as well as yours, is graved upon my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: She is a very odd woman—She wou'd fain persuade me, that I distressed you, by jesting with captain Loyd, about lord Eustace's mistress—I begin to think that she is in love with him, herself—Of what consequence are his galantries to her? I dare say he has had a hundred, of the same sort; and that the lady, to whom he is now going to offer his hand, can have but a very small remnant, of his heart.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have heard him say, Sir, they should never be divided.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
Fine talking, for a libertine, truly!—However, I agree with you, that it is not right, to
make a jest, of those unfortunate women he may have ruined—And I commend your delicacy, upon this occcasion, as I well know it is the result of the most amiable female virtues, modesty, and compassion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What ails my child?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What is the matter? You amaze me, Harriet!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You see, before you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Don't distract me! Whom do I see?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am—lord Eustace—my father!—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Speak; go on—Lord Eustace!—What of him?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am his wife—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What—lord Eustace's wife!—Then you are a wretch, indeed!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yet pardon me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot pardon you! Harriet, you have undone yourself.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O do not say so, Sir, when it is in your power, to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wou'd it were—but there is very little prospect of happiness, for a virtuous woman, who is connected with a libertine.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you have mistaken his character; and when you know him better, I am sure you will be sorry—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: It is you, child, that I fear will have cause to be sorry, for having mistaken his character—young women are but bad judges, of their lovers morals.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My aunt, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, she, I suppose, was privy to the match; he is a lord, and that's enough for her.
I might have expected such a stroke, from her intolerable vanity—But how have I been deceived, in my opinion, both of your duty, and affection to me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My future conduct, Sir, shall prove them both.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: O Harriet! What a disappointment is mine? I hoped to have seen you united to a man of sense, and worth, who wou'd have respected, as well as loved you—Instead of that, you are now joined to one, who, from his too intimate knowledge of the vicious part of your sex, is likely to despise them all.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I flatter myself, Sir, that the goodness, both of his heart, and understanding, will make him readily renounce any light errors, he may have fallen into.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wish it, most sincerely—but—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do not, Sir, injure him, by doubting it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I fear, my child, you flatter yourself, in vain, with any change in your husband's conduct—that last amour, which captain Loyd spoke of—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How blest am I, to be able to acquit my lord!—Tho' blushing I avow it, it was his mysterious attachment to his wife, that caus'd that vile report.—O Sir! let me, again, upon my knees, entreat you to pardon what is past, and give lord Eustace leave to prove the sincerity of his affection, to me, by his respectful tenderness and gratitude, toward you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Rise, rise, my Harriet. Since it is so—I forgive, and bless you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have made your daughter happy—how will lord Eustace be transported!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd see occasion, for this joy! (Aside.)—Retire, my child; compose your spirits, and let me compose mine.—I wish to be alone.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It is almost impossible, Sir!—I am too, too happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Why was this marriage huddled in the dark? It shall not be kept secret—Mystery is the fit mask for vice; my daughter needs it not—I am impatient, 'till I see lord Eustace.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: It is not long, Sir, since he went from hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No matter; leave me, Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If your honour wou'd hear a few words, that I have to say.—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot hear you, now; my thoughts are all engaged. (To himself.)—I must write to colonel Loyd, directly.—I shall have a sad piece of work, with the old gentleman at Trevallin—he doats upon my girl, as if she were his child.—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, and so does every one, who knows her, except some of the folk in this house.—I wish, indeed I do, that we were fairly out of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well, we shall leave it, soon—but, for the present, Robert—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Your honour little knows what's going forward, in it—such quarrelling, such high words! aye, and such fine words, too, as I ne'er heard, before; tho', if I understand them right, they have but a black meaning.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Robert, we'll talk of this, some other time.—I say, again, I am not at leisure, now.—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I can't be easy, 'till I tell you, Sir; as I am sadly afraid there is something a plotting, against your honour, or my young mistress.—I have heard that wicked Willis talking of her, to his fellow servant.—O Sir, that fellow knows all his lord's secrets; he is at the beginning, and ending, of all mischief; and he says, as how Miss Harriet has been only impos'd upon. (Sir Wm. starts.)—Yes, Sir, impos'd upon—
and that his master will be married to a fine lady, in less than a month's time.—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How! impos'd upon! what can this mean? lord Eustace dare not think of any thing so base.—I injure both myself and him, by the suspicion.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: All I know of the matter, is, Sir, that the gentleman that lives here (whom I believe to be a very honest man, tho' Willis calls him a poor rogue) and my lord Eustace, had a sad quarrel, and they talked so loud, that I cou'd not help overhearing Mr. Frampton—for I scorn to listen—reproaching my lord, with having behaved, very ill, both to you, and your daughter—but they were friends, afterwards, and went out, together.—But Willis said a great deal more, to James, my lord's footman, to the same sense—and whatever mischief there is a brewing, I am sure he knows all about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot comprehend the meaning of all this.—Imposed upon!—I will be satisfied—His scoundrel servant talk of my daughter, and of his marriage with another lady!—I have not patience to wait the meeting with lord Eustace—Is that fellow in the house?—That Willis, Robert?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, James and he have been taking a hearty glass, I believe; he looks pure and merry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Bid him come to me, directly.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am afraid he will be too cunning, for your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do, as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wm.
sp.p: The happiness, or misery, of my child, seem now suspended, in an equal balance.—Let my impatience to turn the scale in her favour, excuse me, to myself, for condescending to inquire into another's secrets, tho' they so nearly concern me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Your valet de chambre told me, Sir, that you desired to speak with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Our conversation will be but short, Mr. Willis.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I am in a rare humour, to bam this Welsh Baronet.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I say our conversation will be but short, Mr. Willis; but I shou'd wish it to be sincere.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: There he has hit the mark. (Aside.)—O, to be sure, Sir! I have been remarkable, for truth and sincerity, all my life, Sir. My mother taught me, from a child, never to tell a lie.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Truth is, certainly, the foundation of every other virtue, and I hope I may depend upon yours, to answer a few questions, that I shall ask you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: O yes, you may depend upon me.—What the devil is he about! He is certainly going to hear me my catechism.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I shall think myself obliged to you, if you will acquaint me with what you know, in relation to lord Eustace's marriage.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Me, Sir! How is it possible I can tell?—All's out, I suppose—O that cursed Langwood!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No trifling with me, friend; I will be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Yes, to be sure, Sir, all servants ought to give civil answers to gentlemen; but really, Sir, I cannot possibly tell you any thing about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Since fair means will not prevail upon you, this shall extort the truth.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p:
For heaven's sake, Sir, don't terrify an evidence, in this land of liberty——You will either frighten what I do know, out of my head, or make
me confess any thing, without knowing any thing, at all, of the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No prevarication, Sir—Men, like you, who are bred up in vice and idleness, are to be influenced by nothing, but their fears—Therefore, tell me, I say, again, what you know of this marriage?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, they have had another letter, from Langwood; so I may as well make a merit of giving up ours, since there can be none in keeping it from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What are you muttering, villain? Don't urge me farther; I have lost my reason, and will not answer for the consequences.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I will do any thing, Sir, if you will be pleased to drop the point of that ugly piece of cold iron.—What you have heard from Langwood, is most certainly true.—But a good servant, you know, Sir, ought to keep his master's secrets, till his life is in danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Langwood!—Master's secrets!—Explain yourself, this moment.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Dear Sir, be patient—What need you have the trouble of hearing it over again, when you know it all, already?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Dare you again insult me, with your trifling?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir, I can't say it was a right thing of my lord, but none of his servants were in fault, except Langwood; we must do what our masters bid us; and he, poor devil, is sorry enough, as you know, Sir, and may see, Sir.
sp.stage: (Takes the letter out of his pocket, Sir William snatches it.)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Langwood, again!—Who is Langwood? And what has he to do, with your lord's marriage? And what is this letter?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: It is for Mrs. Winifred, Sir; and as to Langwood, he was the mock-doctor, the counterfeit parson, that married my lord; I was only the clerk, indeed, Sir; and I hope your honour will be so good to forgive me, and not leave all the sin, and the shame, too, upon my poor conscience.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Why, villain! rascal! what is all this stuff? If your lord be married to my daughter, how dare he think of any other wife?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: So, I have made a fine piece of work on't!—I find he did not know it was a sham marriage, till now.— (Aside.) Why, really, Sir, you terrify me so, that I don't rightly understand you; I thought you knew all about it, before I opened my lips to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I asked you, wretch, about your lord's intended marriage?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: O lord, Sir, it was very unlucky I did not understand you. I shall be obliged to fly my country; my lord will never let me live in England, after this. I shall lose an excellent place, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Be gone, thou profligate! Fly from my sight, this moment.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I am an undone scoundrel, that's the truth of it!—But this comes of muddling, in a morning—Had I been sober, I shou'd have been an over-match, for his worship, or any justice of peace, in England. I'll e'en retire, till my master, and this Welch family, have so reconciled matters, between themselves, that a gentleman may be able to live, with some satisfaction, amongst them.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What am I now to think! My child is dishonoured! Let me contain my rage, a moment longer, and be yet more fully satisfied, from their own lips.—Robert!
Go, call my sister, and—I cannot name her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Miss Harriet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Aye, bid them come hither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I never saw my master so disturbed, before.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Of what can they inform me? Do I not know my daughter is undone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Pray, my lady, go first.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Where are these wretched, these unhappy women, that have brought shame, and sorrow, on themselves, and infamy on me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Hey day! What's the matter now? Harriet told me she had just lest you in a heavenly temper; what can have happened, to discompose you, since? but Much Ado about Nothing, is your play, from morning, 'till night.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Read that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: A broken seal! What can be the contents?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do not talk to me, unhappy girl! Lord Eustace has deceived you—you are not his wife.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: All gracious heaven!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Rage and madness! O women, women, what have ye done!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Vastly well, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
You are enough to provoke a saint, yourself.—What is all this stuff, this letter, this forgery, this nonsense! He personate a parson! I
think I shou'd know a clergyman, in any dress. I am not quite so easily impos'd upon, as you, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I will not answer you—But thou, undutiful, unhappy girl! what can'st thou say?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I wish you wou'd hear reason, and spare your reproaches, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No—give them vent—I only fear to live, not die—Let loose your rage, upon me: I implore it; I will endure it all.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You have deserved it. Your own deceit has fallen upon your head; you are betray'd, dishonour'd, and abandon'd, both by your villain husband, and your wretched father.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O Sir! have pity on my anguish and despair!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot bear your sight—My being, life itself, is hateful to me.— (To Mrs. Win.) This is your pride, your rage for quality!—You have undone my child, and I renounce you both!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you forsake me, also?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Forsake you! no, child; this is a perfect chimera of your father's.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O let us go this moment, implore his goodness to forgive our fault, and fly, for ever, from this hateful dwelling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: By no means; I don't approve of your quitting your husband's house. I wou'd have you write to him, immediately, and desire him to come to us, this evening.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I write to him! You make me shudder, at the thought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: It must be done, child—I insist upon it—This is some trick, meant to impose upon us.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I feel the imposition, here—Lord Eustace has betrayed us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I tell you, Harriet, it is impossible—he is at least the ninth peer of his family, in a direct line.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tho' honours may be—honour is not hereditary, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: No matter; write to him, I say: you are, and must be lady Eustace, at any rate, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And can you think me vile enough, after such perfidy, to receive his hand? Can I vow to honour the man, whom I no longer esteem? Shall I go to the altar with him, and swear to be faithful, to a perjur'd wretch? again repeat my vows of everlasting love, for him who has abandoned, and undone me? No; I would sooner die, a thousand, thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: You are just as obstinate, as your father—Now you have taken this into your head, nothing can get it out again.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do you think my father could be so inhuman, without just grounds, to stab me to the heart? It is, it is too true!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I will not believe a word of it.—I never was mistaken, in my life; my brother is ever in the wrong.—I desire, Harriet, you will write to lord Eustace, directly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Indeed, I will not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Then, positively, I will—I am determin'd to know the truth, from him. I own I begin to be a little doubtful, about this matter, myself. This letter may be forg'd—but those eternal reports confound me—'Tis impossible he should dare to deceive me—but if he has, he shall find that the Ap Evans's are not to be injured, with impunity.

div3.head: SCENE, The Park.
div3.stage: Enter Capt. LOYD, and Col. EVANS.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: MY father in London! you surprize me, captain—What can have brought him here?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, as to the matter of surprize, my young hero, your father was quite as much astonish'd, at hearing of your being in the same port, as you can be; and as to your aunt Winifred, she started, with as much amazement, as the sailors that spied the first Patagonian. Your sister, indeed, seem'd more pleas'd, than any of them, at the news, and inquir'd whether I had met you in healthy condition, and if I knew your moorings.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My gentle Harriet!—I am impatient to see her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hoist sail, and away, then; I'll be your convoy, tho' I should like better to drop anchor, and take in refreshment, for an hour or so, at the Admiralty Coffee-house, where I have appointed captain Blast, of the Boreas, and some other jolly lads, to meet me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, captain, but will, by no means, suffer you to break your engagement.—I have a little business to dispatch, before I can see my father, and shall easily find out the house, without troubling you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why, that you may readily do, as it is inclos'd by a very high wall, and has a large handsome gate-way, with a bell at the door.—Aye,
aye, that bell was not plac'd there, to call the crew to prayers, but to prevent the neighbours from knowing who comes in and out, as they might do, if there was a rapper only.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I can't see why that caution should be necessary.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is of no great use, at present—But time has been—Harkee me, Harry, there is a devilish storm brewing over your head; you may look for dirty weather, I can tell you—Your father is in a confounded passion, at your having quitted the regiment, and is strongly persuaded that you'll spring a leak, my boy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wrote to my father, some time ago, to acquaint him with my motives; I have also written to my colonel, to account for my conduct.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Never fear, I'll take care of you, as I am sure you did not desert, from cowardice—But it was a silly trick, Harry.—Some girl, I suppose, is in the wind; they make fools of the wisest of us.—I remember, when I was station'd at Gibraltar, a Donna Isabella—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wou'd you were there, now: I know not how to get rid of this tiresome man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Spaniard, you may guess, by the name, had a devilish mind to come off with me, as she said, to see foreign parts—But I weigh'd anchor, slily, one moon-light night, and left the poor signiora on shore—But all men have not the gift of discretion: tho' I was a younker, then, Harry, not much turn'd of thirty, I'll assure you—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I think it was rather cruel in you, to forsake the lady, captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why, I did hear, afterwards, that there was a ballad made about it, intitled The Cruel Captain's Garland, and set to a very woeful tune—I
laugh at these things, Harry; but I find you are a truer lover, and have come here, in spite of wind and tide, in pursuit of your mistress—You can't expect, however, that Sir William will be highly delighted, if you shou'd happen to make a losing voyage of it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, it will be the most prosperous one of my life, and I shall be able to give my father a satisfactory account, of my conduct.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, if your mistress be well freighted, a sixty thousand pounder, or so, he will have no objection, I suppose.—But come, my boy, tell me a little about it: is she maid, or widow, Harry? I like to hear love-stories, mightily.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She is a maiden, young, and beautiful, and of a rank and fortune, beyond my expectation, captain. We have lov'd one another, long; her guardians are upon the point of disposing of her, to another; she has desir'd me to free her from their tyranny, and accept of her hand, as my reward—Glorious recompence!—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, Harry! this is running before the wind, with a vengeance—Not so fast, not so fast, my boy, you go at the rate of twelve knots, an hour—This story sounds a little romantic, tho', and puts me in mind of the lady, that the flying man comes to save from the monster.—But 'tis odd enough, that I shou'd not know this lady; prithee, Harry, what's her name?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You must excuse my not answering that question, captain, as you might possibly become my rival.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why, to be sure, if she had applied to me, she shou'd have been far enough from her guardians, by this, we'd have run gunnel to, all the way, my
boy, and left them, and you on the dry land, Harry.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I shall tell her of your intended galantry, captain; and I hope you and she will be better acquainted—for the present, I must wish you a good evening.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, if you have a mind to sheer off, colonel, I wish you a fair gale.—I never grapple with any thing, but a pretty lass, or an enemy; and so, your servant, your servant, colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My meeting with this blundering sailor, was unlucky, as my father may, perhaps, be displeas'd at my not waiting on him, the moment I knew of his being in London.—But I cannot break my engagement, with lady Anne—every thing must give way, to that charming woman—I will fly to her, directly, and, if possible, find time to pay my duty to my father, before I sleep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: He will come, then; you have staid a great while, Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My lord was not at home, madam; and as you desir'd I shou'd bring an answer, I was oblig'd to wait his coming—Every thing seems in confusion, in the family; his lordship, it seems, is to be married, in a few days; they are all packing up, and the servants scarce knew where to find pen, ink, and paper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
This startles me—'Tis but too plain I have been deceived. (Aside.)—Hearken to me, Robert, and do, exactly, what I command you—go
and place yourself by the private door, in the garden, and the moment you hear a key turn in the lock, come and tell me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I shall obey you, madam.—I am sure all is not right. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I must, if possible, prevent Sir William's knowing of this interview—But here he comes—
—I hope you have vented all your rage, brother, and that one may talk, a little calmly, to you, now?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: O yes! I have great reason to be calm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I can tell you that a little more of your outrageous fury, wou'd have kill'd your daughter; nor do I know what fatal effect it might have had, upon my own constitution.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: That is not very easily shock'd, I believe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: That is more than you know, at least, brother; but a person so intirely given up to their passions, never once reflects upon consequences.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wish you had reflected upon consequences; but those who have err'd themselves, are ever ready to reflect on others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: A truce with reflections, on all sides; and in case that there shou'd be any truth, in this infamous story, let us set about forming some scheme, for redressing the affront, that he has dar'd offer to our family.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I shall not stand in need of your assistance. I am determin'd how to act.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Pray, Sir William, do not be headstrong, but, for once, be advised by me.—I have thought of a scheme, and I am sure it will answer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: It is happy for my family, that I have a little sense, brother, tho' I do not boast of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your wisdom in this matter, has been conspicuous; but what new proofs of it, are we to expect, at present?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Suppose we were to send for lord Eustace, and try what effect Harriet's tears, and my reproaches, wou'd have upon him—He has always had the greatest deference, for my opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your opinion!—Is this your boasted scheme?—He will not come; base as he is, it is impossible he cou'd endure her sight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Your affected sagacity is enough to set one mad—You are mistaken, as you always are.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I know it cannot be; the consciousness of his vile treachery, will keep him far from hence.—He dare not see her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I cannot bear this contradiction. (Aside.)—For once let conviction conquer your obstinacy: I wrote to him, myself, in Harriet's name; I have had his answer; he will be here, this night.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And shall my daughter sue to him, for justice? implore him to receive the hand he has rejected, and the heart he has betray'd? Shall she be sacrific'd, to make his peace? I tell you, no—I will have other vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I see these horrid punctilios will ruin all—If we can make up this matter quietly, what does it signify, whether he be a man of honor, or no?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I never must forget, that I am one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I wish you wou'd have a little patience, and hear me out—If this should fail, I have another project, in my head, which I am certain must succeed—My imagination has not been idle, and I think it full as active, as your own.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I believe it may be rather more so—But I have no leisure, for imaginary matters, now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Pray, Sir William, don't be so positive—you know lord Eustace has a place, at court.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I wou'd, at least, let the king know what a servant he has about him; and as I may reasonably suppose that his majesty may have heard of our ancestors, tho' he knows nothing of you, Sir William, I wou'd advise you to throw yourself, at his feet—He is himself a father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Blest may he long be, in that honour'd title! tho' I am render'd wretched, by the name—But what can he do, for me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Disgrace, and displace the man, who has wrong'd you, altho' he be a lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What is his title? has he not debas'd it—But know, there is no difference of rank, before the throne—degrees of elevation, are only seen by those, who look above them: kings must look down, and therefore see all equal; and in our monarch's sight, the rights, even of the meanest subject, are precious as his own—But yet he cannot heal my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Tho' I can never believe that a knight baronet is upon a par, with a lord, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Absurd distinctions! I will hear no more—The man who has the means of justice, in his own hands, and seeks for it elsewhere, deserves to be the sport of chance, and dupe of his own weakness—Then let him come, this night—I'll meet him as I ought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
You are exactly in the same case, of the Dissidents, at Warsaw; nothing, but force of arms, will content you; and like them, too, you may be
undone, by it—Suppose you were to meet lord Eustace, and he shou'd kill you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I shall not, then, out-live my honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: This self-will'd man distresses me, extremely—he is, for ever, disconcerting my schemes—There never was such a race of ideots, as the family of the Ap Evans's, myself excepted—there is not a head, in this house, but my own—To be sure I have been a little over-reach'd, in this affair of the wedding; but the greatest politicians are liable to mistakes—I hope to repair all, yet, and make my niece a woman of quality, one way, or another.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Madam, I have just now heard the private door of the garden, unlock, and ran to tell you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Vanish! (Exit Rob.) I must not let my brother and lord Eustace meet, 'till every thing is settled.

div3.head: SCENE, Garden Parlour.
div3.stage: Enter Lord EUSTACE and Col. EVANS, with their Swords in their Hands, Lord EUSTACE lays his on a Chair.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: You are here in safety, Sir, and may put up your sword; this house is mine, notwithstanding the mysterious manner of my entrance—I hope you are not wounded?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Thanks to your courage, and generosity, Sir, I have escaped unhurt. I thought our police was better conducted, than to suffer our lives to be endangered, by footpads.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: These accidents are less frequent, in this country, than they used to be; but no code of laws was ever yet framed, that cou'd make all men honest.—I am extremely happy, at having come so opportunely, to your assistance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I shall ever be grateful, for the obligation, Sir; but may I not know to whom I am obliged?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Do not mention the matter as a favour, I intreat you—You wou'd, doubtless, have done the same for me; and had I happen'd to have come first, I shou'd have stood in need of your assistance—I am call'd lord Eustace.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I shall remain indebted to your lordship, and wish you a good night.—What a rencontre!

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I could wish you not to leave me, Sir; 'tis late, and therefore unsafe for either of us, to return alone—The fellows who attacked you, may lye in wait for you—I shall not stay here a quarter of an hour; and as I wish to be better acquainted with you, I shou'd be glad to know your address.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am extremely obliged to your lordship. I am call'd colonel Weston; you'll hear of me, at the hotel in Pall-mall.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Let me entreat you not to leave me—I am, at present, in a very difficult, and disagreeable situation.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your lordship has a right to command me; but I hope you will not stay longer than the time you have mention'd, as I have some business to transact, this night.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: If that be the case, I will not trespass upon you; perhaps, there may be something similar, in our circumstances; for your business, at this hour, must, in all probability, be with a lady, and you may reasonably suppose, by my being alone, and on foot, that I am come to meet one, here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Let me entreat your lordship not to lose such precious minutes, but fly to the expecting fair one.—This is an odd discovery.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: The matter is not as you imagine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There is, perhaps, a jealous husband, or an old cross father, my lord—

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Neither, colonel. But matches, made for interest, only, too often break the most delightful ties, the union of fond hearts—The lady, who lives here, is the most amiable of her sex, and I adore her; yet, am on the point of marrying one, whom I can never love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is a sad affair, indeed, my lord.—I cou'd save you a great deal of trouble, if I were at liberty to tell you lady Anne's intentions.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I fear the unhappy girl has heard of my intended marriage, as she has written to me to come here, this night—I never was so embarras'd, or distress'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Some girl you keep, I presume, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: By no means; she is a woman of family and character—I am almost distracted about her—I will now step and see if the coast be clear, as there are some of the family, that I shou'd not chuse to encounter, at this late hour, and return to you, Sir, instantly—You see what confidence you have already inspired me with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
A confidence, indeed! but of what use can it be to me, who am bound in honor, not to betray it? (Looks at his watch.) Bless me, it is now past eleven—the time I spent with lady Anne, stole unperceived away. It will certainly be too late, to go to my father's, to-night; I must defer my visit, 'till to-morrow; and as lord Eustace don't seem in a great hurry to be married, I shall have time enough to get lady Anne out of her guardian's power, and
prepare my father for her reception—But here comes my new friend.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: All is quiet; I must therefore, take the opportunity of conveying you safe out, again; and I hope to have the pleasure of being better known to you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your lordship's inclination does me honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Your obstinacy is enough to distract me—I say you shall see him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Support me, gracious Heav'n!

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: My dearest Harriet, your billet has alarm'd me, more than I can express—I have made the utmost dispatch that was possible, to fly to you; and the moments that have passed, since I received your commands, have been the most painful of my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Your lordship need not enter into a defence of your punctuality.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Why is my Harriet's brow overcast? and her eyes quenched in tears? Why is she silent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Ask your own heart!

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Is it possible that the idle report of my marriage, can have distress'd her, thus?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Horrid dissembler!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Do not exhaust your spirits, my dear Harriet; give me leave to talk to him (Aside to Harriet.)—So then, my lord, what we have heard upon the subject, is but an idle report, without the least foundation?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: If you will but recollect, what has pass'd between your niece and me, madam, you must be fully convinced it can be nothing more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: And yet, my lord, you seem, confused.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Why really, madam, the doubts you seem to entertain of my veracity, are a little distressing—But let me hope my Harriet will believe me, while I swear—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Away, my lord! I can believe no more—Cou'd I have thought that either my wrongs, or my resentment, were capable of increase!

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Really, madam, I do not clearly understand the meaning of this conversation—and I must say, I think it rather severe, to be condemn'd, unheard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I can contain my rage, no longer; read that.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Langwood's letter! All is discover'd, then!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I perceive that even a man of quality, may be disconcerted—Your lordship did not use to be at a loss, for an answer.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Have patience, madam; I confess that appearances are against me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Aye, and realities, too, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p:
I do not mean to justify myself—No, I plead guilty. The fear of losing you, my Harriet, whom I lov'd more than life, and the apprehension of disobliging my father, tempted me to
make you mine, in an illegal manner—But here I swear, I will repair the injury.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I think it will do; matters are in a right train, now, if I can but prevent Sir William from interrupting them.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: You are offended, Harriet, and have cause—but let not your resentment turn against yourself.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Cou'd I forgive myself, my lord, I then might pardon you; but while I think my punishment severe, I own I have deserved it.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: You judge yourself, too hardly—Has either your virtue, or your delicacy, suffered, by my crime? Nay, even your reputation is still free from stain; and if you will now condescend to accept my hand, my future life shall be devoted to your happiness.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And can you think I'll be again deceived?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: By heaven, you shall not!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay, I will not—Your poor evasions have no weight with me—Leave me, for ever leave me—I will not be united to you, by any ties.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Yet hear me, Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Wou'd I had never heard you—But tho' I were to listen to you, now, you cannot shake my purpose. No—I can die!—

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: No, live, my Harriet! Live, to make me happy—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Where is he? I must, and will, see him.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Ah! Sir William! This is unlucky! I am not prepar'd, for this encounter

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What! is it possible that you shou'd dare to enter underneath this roof?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: What shou'd I fear, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your own base heart, and my much injur'd honour; which calls upon you, now, for justice.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: So then, I find the pride of injur'd virtue, was assumed—Your daughter would secure me, by compulsion—But I despise assassins!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do not, my lord, insult my patience, farther; I did not know you were without a sword: on that account, I put up mine; but know, young man, I shall not rest, till it has done me justice.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Sir William, tho' I cannot pretend to justify the injuries I have done your daughter, I neither must, nor will be compell'd, to make the reparation; I shou'd, indeed, be unworthy to become her husband, if fear cou'd make me so.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: At the first hour you saw her, Sir, I shou'd have deemed you so—'Tis not your birth, young man, can varnish over vices, such as yours—Your rank renders them the more obnoxious.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I readily allow myself to blame, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You cannot then be base enough, to refuse the sole atonement, which is now within your power—

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I will confess I felt my heart fubdued, by Harriet's grief, and tenderness—they had more power, than armies—She might have triumphed over me, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You surely do not think I mean to give my daughter to you! What! to reward your vices, with a heart like hers—to have my child become, a second time, a sacrisice to that vain idol, Title!—No, Sir, it is another kind of reparation, I demand; and I will have it.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p:
A brave man, Sir William, never thinks meanly, of another's courage; and as I know you to
be so, I hope you will not think me otherwise, if I decline your offer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: On what pretence, my lord? Have you not wrong'd me?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: For that reason, only, I cannot, dare not, draw my sword against you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: These are new rules of honour, form'd on the principles of fear, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Fear, Sir William!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, I say it; none but a coward, ever will decline to meet the man he has injured; and shou'd you still persist in your refusal, I will proclaim you one.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: This is too much—But consider, Sir, you are—my Harriet's father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: That consideration wou'd brace a nerveless arm—But, look upon me, Sir; I am not bent beneath the weight of years—my mind and body both, are firm as yours; and the first shock that ever reach'd my heart, except her mother's loss, is the disgrace you have brought upon my child—The stain must be effac'd, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I know not how to act; shou'd I declare my intention to marry Harriet, he wou'd despise me; and if I fight him, that renders it impossible.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Come, come, my lord, this is no time for musing—You must determine, instantly, to give me the satisfaction I require, or see your title posted up, with the honourable addition, of coward, to it.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Nay, then, Sir William, tho' with reluctance, I must accept your offer—Name your time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: At eight, to-morrow morning—

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p:
I'll call upon you, Sir, and bring a friend—But let me once more add, that you are the
only man, on earth, that I shou'd fear to meet, upon such terms▪

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I am glad my son is ignorant, of this affair—Had he been here, he must have fought lord Eustace—He has, I hope, a long, and happy life, before him; mine, tho' not quite worn out, is of less value; and if I lose it, in defence of my child's honour, 'tis well disposed of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: So she was, or might have been, very well dispos'd of, but for your intemperance—You have managed your matters, very cleverly, to be sure—You have driven lord Eustace away, and the family of the Ap Evans's are disgrac'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Thou weak, vain, woman! whose folly has undone me, and my child.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Not I truly, Sir William—It is her own high-flown principles, that have ruined her—My lord offered to marry her, over and over again, it seems, but she with her nonsensical, romantical notions, affected to despise him, and refused to be his wife, on any terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Has she? I rejoice, to hear it—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Rejoice; at what! at her being a mad woman? I think, in her situation, she needed not have been so nice—It would have been much better for her, to have been lady Eustace, even against his will, than Miss Harriet Evans's, against her own.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How nearly pride, and meanness, are allied! You wou'd obtrude your niece, upon a man, who has abandoned, and dishonour'd her; then vainly think she might receive distinction, from a title, which force, not choice, bestowed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
Brother, I neither understand logic, nor sophistry, but I am very sorry matters are as they are.
—As to Harriet, I believe it will be of no great consequence, to her; she will soon break her heart, I imagine—But the scandal of this affair, will rest upon the survivors.—I don't think I shall ever be able to shew my face, at Monmouth, again.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Away! The moments now are too precious, to be wasted. Where is Harriet?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: In her chamber, like a distracted wretch, tearing herself to pieces. I endeavoured to comfort her, as much as I could, by telling her how wrong she had acted, and that she might have lived to be a countess, if he had followed my advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Was this the consolation you offer'd to her grief? How cou'd you be so barbarous? The proper spirit she has shewn, in refusing that worthless lord, has replaced her in my heart—I will go try to comfort her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Aye, so you may; you are the fittest to go together. For my part, I disclaim the mismanagment of this whole affair; and remember, I'll no longer be accountable, for measures, that I am not suffer'd to guide.

div3.head: SCENE, Mr. Frampton's Apartment.
div3.stage: Ld EUSTACE and Mr. FRAMPTON discovered.
Lord Eustace rises from a Table, as if writing.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: YOUR meeting with Sir William, was extremely unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I most sincerely wish we had not met; but that is past—

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Then I suppose you think the worst is over.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: No, Frampton, 'tis to come.—Sir William has insisted upon my meeting him, this morning.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Impossible, my lord! you must not fight him. Think on the consequences: if you should be so unhappy, as to kill the father of the woman you have highly injured, the world wou'd certainly unite against you, and drive you from society.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: In that case, I shou'd be but ill qualified, for solitude, I confess.—Now, my dear Frampton, as I know you are my friend, and as I wou'd not wish any other person shou'd be acquainted with this story, I must desire you will be my second.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p:
It is much beneath a man of honour, to make professions, either of his friendship, or his courage; but, on this occasion, I must tell you, that I wou'd hazard my life, for your service, in any other cause; but I will not be concern'd, in this
infamous affair; and, I say, again, you must not raise your arm, against Sir William.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: You do not know how I am circumstanced. He has compell'd me, to this duel; said he wou'd brand me, for a coward, if I declin'd it.—What wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Marry his daughter.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: No—Tho' I love her, with the truest fondness, I will not wed her, upon such terms; nor suffer her to think so meanly of me, as to suppose I poorly barter'd a coward's hand, to save his worthless life.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Yet, consider, my lord, that let the consequences of this duel, be what they may, nothing can acquit you of that justice, you owe, both to her, and yourself.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I own that I have greatly wrong'd her.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: It is now within your power, to make reparation, by becoming her husband; but shou'd you deprive her of a father, she never can be united to the man who kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I will not kill him, Frampton—Urge me, no farther—My mind is torn to pieces.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Believe me, my lord, you are not in a right course, to heal it.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: No matter; you have refus'd to be a witness of my conduct, Mr. Frampton.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: And do so, still: I never had the least reason to doubt your bravery; and as this is an affair, in which only principals can be concern'd, I hope it will be no imputation, upon mine, if I decline seeing your lordship engaged in a strife, where I cannot wish you success.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I shall not press you; but have yet a request to make.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Name it, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: If I should fall, deliver this letter, to my father; and—if there be any circumstance of my misconduct, left untold, which may do Harriet justice, inform him of it, fully.—I must now go seek, for a less cautious friend, than Mr. Frampton.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Your lordship will scarcely ever find a sincerer. (Exit lord Eustace.) Of what opposite qualities, is this young man compounded? What a mixture, of good, and evil! But are we not all made of the same materials? The devil himself cannot always mislead a man, that has principles; they will recur, in spite of him, and make their owner act rightly, upon trying occasions.—This letter to his father, shews him to be a man of honor.—Something must be done, to preserve him.—I cannot give him up.—An experiment, tho' a hazardous one, must be made, directly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When shall my tortured mind find rest! Gracious heaven, preserve me from distraction! Perhaps, in a few moments, my father's sword may pierce my husband's heart.—Why has that tender name escap'd my lips? Resentment should have stopt its passage to my tongue, and sighs opposed its utterance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I don't see any harm, child, in your calling him your husband, tho' to be sure he is not so, in law.—But I wou'd have you hope the best, Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
No, I will hope no more—What shou'd I hope?—My pride, my reason might have scorn'd him, living, but I will love him, and lament him,
dead?—Wou'd I had died, the hour before I listen'd to your counsel, and set at nought, the authority of my father.—Your cruel kindness has undone me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I shou'd not have thought of meeting such a return, for that kindness, from you, Miss Evans.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Forgive, and pity my distraction, madam! 'Tis I that have brought ruin, on ye all—But if you ever loved me, think of some means, to find my brother out: he may prevent this duel, and save me from the lowest depth of misery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Really, child, you are extremely ignorant; you talk as if you were at Mohmouth, where our family are known, and properly respected—but in such a place as London, it may possibly be as difficult, to find out an Ap Evans, as any of those mushroom gentry, whose Table does not contain above three generations.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My dearest aunt, do not place bars before my only hope; let all our servants be sent out to seek him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Well, child, if it will make you easy, they shall go, directly; tho' I am of opinion it will be but a fruitless inquiry. But the being too easily prevail'd upon, is my greatest foible—I wish I had a little of Sir William's obstinacy, about me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Consider, madam, I am on the rack; do not lose time, I beg of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
Well, be composed, I will send them; they shall search all the genteel coffee-houses, at the West end of the town—it is impossible he shou'd be in the city.—But don't let your father know, that I told you of the duel: he thinks women are never to be trusted with any thing; and has no
more respect for the empress-queen, or the czarina that I have for a county justice.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How can she be insensible, to griefs like mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What, up so early, Harriet! Who has disturbed your rest?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O Sir! where is that powerful opiate to be found, that can restore it?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: The consciousness of your own heart, and my forgiveness of your only fault, shou'd set your mind at peace.

sp.speaker: Har..
sp.p: What! while that fault endangers your dear life, and robs my brother of the best of fathers?—unworthy as I am to call you by that name.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Her grief almost unmans me. (Aside.)—Why are you agitated thus?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O do not make my brother hate me, too!—Will he not call me parricide?—or if—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Who has acquainted you, with this affair? I did not think there was a heart so brutal.—But do not, Harriet, thus alarm yourself—all may be yet repaired.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Never, Sir, never! for here I vow, that shou'd lord Eustace arm his hand, against your life, no power on earth, shall ever make me his.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Harriet, the laws of honour must be satisfied; and when I was first blest, with the fond name of father, yours then became my most peculiar care; nor life, nor aught on earth, is half so dear to me.—Nay, Harriet, do not weep! I blame you not; your youth, and innocence, have been deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
You are too good, too gentle to me, Sir; I have deserv'd all the distress I feel.—Yet hear me,
Sir—If this must be—might not my brother, Sir, dear as he is to me—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My determination cannot now be alter'd: retire, my child.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Captain Loyd, Sir, desires to see your honor.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Shew him up.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Leave me, my Harriet, leave me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My heart bleeds for her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have crouded all the sail I cou'd make, to come up with you, baronet; and now that I am here, I should be glad to know, in what soundings we are, and whether we are to steer starboard, or larboard?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My letter, I believe, captain, must have given you to understand the reason, of my desiring to see you; at present, I am unhappily engaged, in a duel, and the opinion I have, both of your bravery, and friendship, made me look upon you as the properest person of my acquaintance, to be my second.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As to that matter, Sir William, I think, I have discharged as many broadsides, as any gentleman in the navy—tho' I never yet drew a trigger, out of the line; but powder and ball, I suppose, do pretty much the same execution, by land, as by sea; tho' standing fair to the windward, is, sometimes, of great use to us, baronet.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: It is of little consequence, which way the wind sits, at present, captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I can't say much to that, Sir William.—But I wish you had acquainted me with this business, a day or two ago, I shou'd have lik'd to have made a little will—But, 'tis no great matter, neither—For if I should pop over, you daughter's husband will be my heir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: There is not the least occasion, for that precaution, captain, as your life will not be endanger'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How so? When the ship is once engaged, must not every man aboard her, fight? All but the chaplain, and he shou'd be busy, in his way, too.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: In this case, my friend, you need be no farther concern'd, than to see that the laws of honor, are not violated.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir William! this may do, for some of your fresh water sparks, but Jerry Loyd will never lie to, when the signal's given for chace—no lug-sail work, for me; I shall come pouring down upon them.—But, pray, who is your antagonist? And what is the cause of your quarrel? Was it a drunken business?—I was pretty jolly, myself, last night, but don't remember that I had words, with any one, except the waiter.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I shou'd be asham'd, captain, were I weak enough to run into one vice, from the consequences of another, or hazard my life, this day, for having been guilty of excess, last night.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well! if that is not the case, I don't know what it is. For I think you are not quarrelsome, when you are sober.—But have you breakfasted? Tho' you may have no great appetite, my stomach has been ready for a mess, this half hour, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: We shall find every thing prepar'd, in the next room.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let us make to the store-room, directly; and while we are laying in our provisions, you may tell me who is your man, and all about it.
sp.stage: Enter Lord EUSTACE, Colonel EVANS, and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Let your master know, that I am here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is the most romantic affair, my lord, that ever I heard of. To set out determined to stand your enemy's fire, without returning it!

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: The wrongs, I have done him, and his family, shou'd be atoned, and not increased, colonel; and were it now within my power, I wou'd not take his life, even to save my own.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There I think you are right, my lord; but I can't say I shou'd carry-my politeness, so far, as to make him a compliment, of mine.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: There is something much higher than politeness, in the question, at present—justice, colonel—A man may dispense with the one, but not the other.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am intirely of your opinion; but as your sentiments are so very delicate, and that you really love the girl, why may not I, as your second, step in, and save the explosion of gunpowder, and the lady's character, by preventing the duel?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I will not suffer it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As you intend to offer her your hand, when this business is over, I don't see why you shou'd run the hazard, of losing life or limb; and if the father be a man of honor, as you say he is, I shou'd think—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will not be restrained! No, I will rush between their cruel swords!
sp.stage: Enter, at the same Instant, at opposite Doors, Sir WILLIAM, and HARRIET.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My brother, here! then heaven has heard my prayer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My son!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you not speak to me?
sp.stage: (To the Col. who turns from her.)

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Are you her brother?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, I have that dishonour—Ill fated girl!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What can this mean? Are you come hither, to abet the man, who has disgraced your sister?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My father can't suppose it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Retire, this moment, then, and take her with you—My lord, I am ready to attend you, singly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You shall not go, for I will cling, for ever, here.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I cannot bear this sight—Pray hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Take her away. (To the Col.) This is no time for expostulation—Come, my lord—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay then, Sir, I must interfere—I cannot suffer you to turn assassin, even for her—Lord Eustace has not charg'd his pistols, nor does he mean to raise his arm against you—You cannot take his life, upon these terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Does he despise me, then?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A little gleam of hope, breaks in upon me.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Your son can answer that, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: With truth, my lord, I say you do not—Now, you must answer me.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Your being perfectly acquainted with my intentions, towards your sister, before I knew that you were related to her, shou'd, I think, be a sufficient answer, to any demand you can possibly have to make.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By no means, my lord; tho' your tenderness for the weakness you have caused, may incline you to repair her lost honor, I must and will, be guardian of my own; and nothing but your meeting me, on fair and equal terms, can heal the wound you have given it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Now, Harry, you are my son.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Inhuman brother! will nothing, but his life, content your rage? Let me die for him.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: My angel Harriet!—But since it must be so, I am ready, colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope your lordship thinks I stand acquitted of my obligations to you, by preventing your engaging, on such unequal terms, for that unworthy girl.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: You wrong her much; it is I alone am guilty.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: It is true, my son; Harriet is innocent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If that be true, I have a double right to vengeance!

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: You have a right to chuse your reparation, Sir, and I attend you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When shall my miseries end!
sp.stage: As Lord EUSTACE, and Col. EVANS, are going off, Enter Mr. FRAMPTON.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: I hope, this moment, madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Frampton!

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p:
I have no sort of business, with your lordship,
my commission is directed to Sir William Evans, and lady Eustace.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do not insult me, Sir; I am not lady Eustace.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Nor ever shall be.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: That is a point, that will not, I think, admit of being contested.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Sir; but this is trifling.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I am on the rack—explain yourself, my friend.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: You must give me leave to speak, then—When I saw the distress, and anxiety of your mind, I was fully satisfied of your honourable intentions, towards this lady, from the letter you entrusted me with, which yet remains unopened.—I determin'd, if possible, to preserve both your life, and honour, for her sake, by preventing your duel, with her father, and your marriage, with lady Anne Mountfort.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The first event, Sir, has been prevented, without your assistance, and I will venture to promise, that the second shall never take place.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: I am quite of your opinion, Sir. As I came, this moment from lord Delville, to acknowledge this fair lady, as his son's wife—but this letter Sir William, will more fully explain his lordship's sentiments.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: My generous friend! my guardian angel!

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: My lord, I neither desire, nor deserve, your thanks.—If I have been, in any way, serviceable to you, attribute it to my real attachment, to your truly amiable wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I do not understand all this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: 'Tis as I guess'd, exactly.—All smoke, and no fire.—My nephew, here! Then something may be done—I rejoice to see you, Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Lord Delville has behav'd, like a man of honour; but yet I must inform you, Sir, that the generosity of his conduct, cannot efface the baseness of his son—My daughter shall never be his wife—He has disgrac'd her.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Never, Sir! Here is my witness—this letter, which I now entreat my Harriet to peruse, will fully prove, that had I fallen by your hand, her honour wou'd have been preserv'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will not read it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I think that was behaving like a man of quality.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, Sir William, to look it over, as I can, with truth and honour, attest the sincerity of the writer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There need no farther vouchers. Let Harriet now determine, for herself.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The struggle is too great.—I cannot speak—Leave me, my lord—

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Never, whilst I have life, will I forsake you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It cannot be, my lord—Tho' I have the highest sense of gratitude, for lord Delville's goodness to me, and tho' I believe you perfectly sincere, in what you say, at present; yet the humiliating situation, into which you have plunged me, the distress you have brought upon my family, your attachment to another lady——

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: With shame I must confess my trifling with a lady, whom I cou'd not have lov'd, even had my Harriet been unknown to me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I think I may venture to assure your lordship, that lady Anne Mountfort will be very ready to forgive your want of passion for her, as her partiality for me, might, perhaps, have been the cause of her blindness, to your superior merits.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I congratulate your good fortune, colonel; and am indebted to your generosity, for removing every shadow of difficulty, on lady Anne's account.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Nephew, I wish you joy—There will be one wom of quality, at least, in the family.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Weak as I am, my lord, you cannot shake my resolution

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: I have no hope, but in your interposition, Sir: you are her father, and have been most offended; yet you, perhaps, have the goodness to forgive!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Aye, and give, too, my lord; the man who sincerely repents of error, is farther remov'd from vice, than one who has ne'er been guilty—This letter is a sufficient, and convincing proof, of your contrition. Take her; she is, and shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: My wife!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The commands of a father, must not be resisted—O! my lord, how different are my present sensations, from those I sustained, when I ventur'd to bestow this hand, without his sanction!—But take it; it is yours, for ever, now.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p: Then every wish of my fond heart is accomplished.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Joy to your lordship, and my dearest Harriet!

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: I sincerely wish your ladyship all the happiness, which I well know you have deserv'd.

sp.speaker: Ld Eust.
sp.p:
And you, my friend, shall share it with us, who have steer'd my course to this blest harbour, thro' all the shoals and quick-sands of my folly.
—You shall be happy, too, if ought within my fortune, or my power, can render you so.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Continue to preserve your present bliss, my lord, and I am over-paid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I think I have a right to partake, in your ladyship's felicity, from the principal share I have had, in bringing this event to pass. I hope that lord Delville has been properly inform'd—
—That man is my perpetual torment.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, hey-day, Sir William! What wind's a blowing, now? You seem to have cast anchor, when I thought you were putting out to sea.—Here is the whole crew assembled; Miss Winifred, and all.—Do women fight duels? If I had them on board the Dreadnought, I'd clap them all under hatches, before she engaged.—But come along, baronet, you don't mean to slack sail, now, I hope—I thought, by this time, we shou'd have made a few eyelet holes, in the enemy's rigging.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I hope, my good friend, you will excuse my seeming inattention, to your impatient bravery, when I tell you, that our contest has ended happily, and that you may now wish all this company, as well as lord Eustace, joy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He is to be married, then, it seems—I hope, madam, you'll believe me, another time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Yes, when you tell truth, captain—But, at present, you happen to be a little out, in your soundings, for the ship's name is not the lady Anne, but the lovely Harriet—The country girl, you talked of.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Well, well, all is one to me.—So she is bound for the port of matrimony, I am content—
and so I wish your lordship, your ladyship, and all your ships, a prosperous voyage, to the island of happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.l: They promise fair, to reach that wish'd-for port:
For virtue, tho' of winds and waves the sport,
By passions shaken, and by danger crost,
On life's great sea, is never wholly lost.
Some power divine conducts her swelling sails,
And, of her due reward, she seldom fails.

div1.head: EPILOGUE, Written by the Author of the PROLOGUE, And Spoken by Mrs. CLIVE.
div1.l: I LONG to know, dread Sirs, with due submission,
How you approve me, as a politician?
The thought was mine.—I told the scrib'ling dame,
This part of Winifred, is much too tame;
Ask but the town, said I, they'll all agree,
That a tame character, will not suit me:
I hate such lifeless, water-gruel stuff;
Quicken her well, with politicks, and snuff:
Small quantities of both, will be but teizing;
Give them enough, and set the town a sneezing.
Her scribbling vanity at this was stung;
Would have disputed—Hold, says I, you're wrong,
Don't be so rash, to draw on me, your tongue;
I have a weapon, should I take the field,

l.hi: A better, never did a woman wield;

div1.l: You'll find, when once my passion is afloat,
The soul of Caesar, in a petticoat!
"Aye, but," says she, "in politicks there's danger,
"To courts, and state affairs, I'm quite a stranger."
So much the better, thou most simple woman,
Blunders, in politicks, are not uncommon.
When you mistake, the town will think you clever,
Think that you mean great folks, and clap, for ever;
Old England, like a boy, loves wicked fun,
Abuse your betters, and your work is done.
Small game the English spirit will not follow,
'Tis at the nobler chace, you whoop, and hollow!
O'er hedge, and ditch, you helter skelter fly.
Start but a statesman—Yoax! the hounds full cry!
To pick up lesser game, you will not stay,
While the fox runs, the hare may steal away;
Our auth'ress is the hare—who trembling sits,
'Till she escapes this dreadful pack of wits;
She hopes you will not hunt her, she's so small,
But hark to mercy, as the noblest call.

div1.head: AN EPILOGUE, Written by HENRY JAMES PYE, Esq

lg.l: WELL! after much perplexity and rout,
At length the wished-for wedding's brought about.
A foolish girl! so near to throw away
Love, rank, and reputation, in a day.
And all for what? from prejudice, in truth,
Tho' christened delicacy, now, forsooth.
If (sentimental nonsense thrown aside)
To cards, and politics, she had applied,
For common cares, her soul had been too great,
And only felt an ardor, for the state;
Had glow'd alone with freedom's glorious flame,
And next to PAM's, had honour'd PAOLI's name.
Twice in our annals, baffled France and Spain
Have wept the glories of a female reign:
With great success I think we now might try
The influence of a female ministry.
In private life how well we're used to sway,
More husbands know, than you'll persuade to say;
And how finances properly to rule,
All ladies learn, who ever kept a pool.
Ye generous spirits, who approve my plan,
And wish at least an equal sway with man,
(And some malicious wits so bold we find,
To say this comprehends all woman-kind)
In favour of a female bard, to-night,
Boldly assert a Briton's dearest right;
From man, from haughty man's tyrannic laws,
To your decision she submits her cause;
Rests, on your candor, all her hopes and fears,
And only claims—a Trial by her Peers.
